marc:datafield.marc:subfield: John Taylor Gilman was Governor of New Hampshire (1794-1805, 1813-1816)
Letter commenting on the 1805 gubenatorial election and on social life in Exeter, New Hampshire, and Portland, Maine.
John Borthwick Gilchrist was a surgeon, philologist, linguist, and surgeon, born and educated in Edinburgh.

Letters by Gilchrist chiefly regarding Gilchrist family origins and history, including his father's disappearance and rumored second marriage in America. Collection includes two poems by James Lunn Gilchrist.
William Branch Giles letters and papers,
William Branch Giles was a Senator and Governor of Virginia (1827-1830).
Miscellaneous letters and papers, including three documents signed by Giles as governor of Virginia.
Personal letters to and from Nathaniel Gilman and members of his family. Includes mention of studies at Harvard University, 1853, and the Massachusetts state constitutional convention, 1853.

Letters to Gilchrist from W. H. Wigg and John C. Singleton describing their respective plantations which they were offerint to Gilchrist for sale. Wiggs' plantation was located on the Okatee River in Saint Luke's Parish, Beaufort District and Singleton's was located on the Congaree River, thirteen miles below Columbia.
U.S. Navel Officer whose family was from Charlotte, N.C.

Diary, chiefly from period (Feb. 1844 to Nov. 1845) when Gibbon was off the coast of South America aboard the U.S. naval ship of war Boston while the navy was protecting U.S. interests during the conflict between Uruguay and Argentina. Also daily accounts given during part of the siege at Vera Cruz, Mexico, March 9-14, 1847.
Gillett family of Canaan, Litchfield County, Connecticut., including Sarah, Jonathan, P.W., and Maria Gillett.
Family letters of a personal nature including one concerning immigration from P. W. Gillette, a real estate dealer and broker.
Business correspondence of a wagonmaker of Newton, Va., giving information on that industry, with technical terms, specifications, and prices.
Samuel Gilman was a Unitarian clergyman and author.
Three personal letters of Samuel Gilman and a holograph manuscript of a poem by Caroline (Howard) Gilman, entitled, "To Miss S. Waring, On her seeing me paint the hearth in my Husband's study.
Gill family of Alamance and Iredell County, North Carolina.

Letters from members of the Gill family dealing for the most part with personal affairs and family business. Contains accounts of the experiences of a girl at High Point Female Seminary, N.C., in 1860, including a description of the burning of books written by Hinton Rowan Helper on the seminary grounds; letters from a soldier in the 33rd North Carolina Regiment during the Civil War; and letters from a soldier in the 42nd North Carolina Regiment, 1862-1864.
High Point Female Seminary (High Point, N.C.)
Personal and business letters of a Charleston, S.C., merchant concerning the state of the cotton market in Charleston and Savannah, Ga., and visits to New York.
Collection consists of miscellaneous Civil War letters of Gibson and others.
Teacher and wife of William Gilbert.

Letter, Dec. 8, 1864, of H.L. Gilbert, a northern woman recounting the conditions of her ocean voyage to New Orleans, impressions of the Louisiana countryside and the life and customs of the people, and the life of northerners and southerners in Louisiana. Mrs. Gilbert taught Sunday School classes in New Orleans.
William Kelly Gibbs of Smith Grove, N.C. graduated from Trinity College (later Duke University) in 1869 as valedictorian of his class.
Lecture notes of a student at Trinity College (Randolph County, N.C.), including samples of his poetry and prose.
Collection consists of Gilmer's observations on the African-American, some of which were directed to the "North Carolina Christian Advocate."

Randall Lee Gibson was born in Versailles, Kentucky, was an attorney, politician, and elected as a member of the U.S. House of Representatives and U.S. Senate, representing Louisiana. He also served as a brigadier general in the Confederate Army during the Civil War.
Daniel C. Gilman was President of the University of California at Berkeley, 1872-1875, and of Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md., 1875-1902.
Letters referring to literary and personal matters.
Business papers of Jacob Giles of Richmond Furnace, Pa., including correspondence with E. F. Cabada & Co. regarding purchase of hoops and one item concerning transfer of land.
Letter from Gilman to his cousin, Arthur Gilman, concerning William Gilman's book, A memoir of Daniel Wadsworth Coit of Norwich, Connecticut.
